s0153: His sons Ping and Shang were enfeoffed with thirty thousand households each, Ping as King of Sishui.'
s0154: Enfeoff Zi Shang with thirty thousand households as King of Sishui.'
s0156: King Ping of Zhending was made King of Zhending as son of King Xian of Changshan in the fourth year of Yuanding.
s0157: King Si of Sishui, Shang, was made King of Sishui as son of King Xian of Changshan in the fourth year of Yuanding.
s0158: He died after eleven years. His son, King Ai Anshi, succeeded him.
s0159: He died after eleven years with no sons.
s0160: The emperor pitied the extinction of the Sishui line and established Anshi's younger brother He as King of Sishui.
s0161: These four kingdoms were originally ruled by sons of Lady Wang and Lady Xu.
s0162: Later Han further enfeoffed their branch descendants as kings of Liu'an and Sishui, two kingdoms.
s0163: Altogether Lady Xu's descendants number six kings to this day.
s0164: The Grand Historian says: In Gaozu's time the feudal lords all contributed taxes, able to appoint their own interior ministers and below. Only Han appointed chancellors for them with gold seals.
s0165: The feudal lords appointed their own censors, court ministers, and erudites, comparable to the Son of Heaven.
s0166: After the Wu and Chu rebellion, the five clans of kings generation after generation, Han appointed officials of two thousand shi for them, removed 'chancellor' and called it 'prime minister', silver seal.
s0167: The feudal lords only received rent taxes, their power was taken away.
s0168: Afterward the impoverished feudal lords sometimes rode ox-carts.
